Elliotte,

It's a good point.  We tried it as a checked exception originally, but I 
felt that it spread to a lot of places that didn't really care about it 
(all the way from running individual methods up to the command-line 
front end), cluttering the interface.  I could take another look and see 
if I still feel that way.  Does anyone else have opinions on this?

A callback didn't really seem the way to go, since there's a single 
thread of control that a Runner can hold onto as long as it wants.  If 
you take a look at the code, and see an opportunity for inserting a 
callback, let us know.

Thanks for all your comments,

    David Saff

Elliotte Harold wrote:

> org.junit.notify.StoppedByUserException is a runtime exception. I think
> this should naturally be a checked exception. A StoppedByUserException
> indicates an environmental condition that may occur on some runs and not
> others. It cannot be tested for or predicted. This is precisely when a
> checked exception is called for.
>
> On a related note, I'm not sure that an exception is really the correct
> way to handle this. Perhaps a callback would work better if this really
> isn't an exceptional condition?
